article.Heading: Expect FY18 GDP at 6.8%: Sajjid Chinoy

article.Body:
Ten months after demonetisation and just 2 months after the launch of the goods and services tax (GST), India's growth rate has dropped to its lowest level since Narendra Modi took charge as Prime Minister.

In an interview to CNBC-TV18, Sajjid Chinoy of JP Morgan, Tanvee Gupta Jain, India Economist at UBS Investment Bank and Manish Wadhawan, MD & Head-Interest Rates at HSBC India shared their readings and outlook on the same.

Forecast for the full year for gross domestic product (GDP) is 6.8 percent which means gross value added (GVA) will be close to 6.5-6.6 percent, Chinoy said.

GDP numbers released yesterday are numbers that drove the August rate cut, he further added.

It was the weaker growth in this quarter that pushed down core inflation, pushed down Reserve Bank of Indiaâ€™s (RBI) inflation forecast, he said.

According to him, if growth does not pick up in the next few quarters, it should put some downward pressure on core inflation.

Tanvee Gupta Jain said we have revised our forecast lower. Expect FY18 GDP at 6.6 percent versus earlier 7.2 percent and GVA at 6.5 percent, she said.

She said they are factoring in one more rate cut from RBI but the timing is uncertain.

Manish Wadhawan said that consolidation in bond markets likely to continue. It will be a wait and watch for Indian bond markets, he added.
